Joe,

When I was looking at lots of Smalltalk code that used Pluggable Selector
the consequence I found most annoying was that I could not delete
seemingly-unreferenced methods because they might be invoked dynamically.

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> Jason Rogers wrote:
> 
> > My point was that instead of using string-based reflection, 
> you have a
> > collection of Adaptors that you can iterate over to get the same
> > behavior.  How do you get the adaptors?  Use a Factory.
> 
> I get it; I really do. I'd like to frame my original question 
> within the 
> context of JUnit itself, and not just to bring this back 
> on-topic.[1] A 
> common way to extract test methods from JUnit (3.x) tests is to use a 
> naming convention with reflection. Assume that we do not have 
> access to 
> metainformation such as annotations. How could we allow 
> people to write 
> tests without having to do the kind of double-entry I prefer 
> not to do? 
> In other words, I just want to write a test and JUnit knows 
> it's a test, 
> rather than having to tell it that. How can we do that without 
> reflection? If there's a way, I want to know about it, because I'd be 
> missing something valuable!
> 
> What I find strange in all this is that I demonstrated doing 
> what JUnit 
> does in another piece of code, and even people who use JUnit 
> looked at 
> me like I was high.[2] Why the double standard? Why does JUnit get to 
> use this pattern and I don't. It's just weird, so I'm looking for an 
> explanation by asking the more general question, "What's so bad about 
> Pluggable Selector?"
> ----
> [1] Personally I don't care whether it's off- or on-topic, but some 
> readers might care.
> 
> [2] Just say no. Stay in school. All that stuff.
